thread.title: Paramedic dad of girl, 15, blasts NHS for cancelling daughter's life-changing back surgery a DAY before operation
thread.title_full: Paramedic dad of girl, 15, blasts NHS for cancelling daughter's life-changing back surgery a DAY before operation

author: Scarlet Howes
title: Paramedic dad of girl, 15, blasts NHS for cancelling daughter's life-changing back surgery a DAY before operation
text:
The teen was scheduled to have life changing spinal surgery in December Share   
The dad of a 15-year-old girl who was due to have life-changing back surgery has blasted the NHS after the operation was cancelled over 'funding issues'. 
Lucy Huddleston suffers from adolescent idiopathic scoliosis, which is an abnormal twisting and curvature of the spine. 
The teen, from Bedlington, South East Northumberland, was scheduled to have life changing spinal surgery in December but the NHS operation was delayed and then cancelled because of funding issues - leaving her family with no choice but to fundraise for the surgery themselves. 
Dad Mark Huddleston said: “We are saddened and frustrated that our 15-year-old daughter was promised this life changing surgery and had it taken away from her at the very last minute. 
"The surgery was scheduled on the NHS for the end of last year but now my family face the prospect of having to cover the costs privately and raise over £160,000 ourselves to allow Lucy to have the operation. 
"It’s deeply upsetting. I am a Paramedic in the NHS and have served and helped the public in their most desperate times for the past 20 years. Now the tables have turned and it is my family that desperately needs the help of the public and that’s why we have set up this GoFundMe appeal .” The 15-year-old's family are deeply upset that the surgery was "taken away from her last minute" 
The curves in Lucy’s back are currently at 55 & 60 degrees in the shape of an ‘S’ and if left un-corrected will increase and stiffen with time leaving her with chronic back pain. 
Due to the twisting nature of scoliosis her ribcage is also rotated and this has produced a visible ‘rib hump’ on the left hand side of her back and a protruding right shoulder blade. 
Mark added: “If the condition continues to get worse it could also have a serious effect on her internal organs. However, the only treatment available in the UK at the moment is called spinal fusion. 
"This operation involves the use of screws, metal rods and a bone graft which would straighten her spine but fuse it all together creating one solid structure. 
"As Lucy has two curves this means the majority of her spine would need to be fused. This would severely restrict her mobility and have a huge effect on her quality of life. As parents we refused to accept that this was the only option and were convinced there must be something better." If Lucy's condition gets worse it could have a serious effect on her internal organs 
After extensive research the family found a procedure called Vertebral Body Tethering (VBT) which has been pioneered in the US. 
In July Lucy had a consultation in London with the only surgeon in the UK who was actively performing this operation. 
Mark said: "Lucy was deemed a candidate and we were absolutely thrilled, feeling like a weight had been lifted off our shoulders. 
“She was scheduled for VBT surgery on 8th December 2016. We even travelled back down to London to undergo all of the pre-operative tests. 
"Despite being so far through the process, we received a devastating phone call in October to inform us that her surgery had been postponed until December. 
“This was due to issues around funding and NHS England took the action of suspending all VBT for the foreseeable future. This also meant that no surgeon could operate privately in the UK." The family have set up a Go Fund Me page in a bid to raise money for Lucy's surgery 
But if and when VBT is resumed new criteria means Lucy will no longer be a candidate. 
"This was a huge blow and left us totally and utterly devastated considering her surgery was planned for the following day," Mark added. 
“The time following this was extremely tough for the whole family, especially Lucy. 
"She became very withdrawn and we felt terrible as we had built her hopes up so much." Like us on Facebook
